required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Bronx Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy for Migraine: a Randomized Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This randomized clinical trial aims to examine the effect of a standardized 8-week course of Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy for Migraine on migraine-related disability in people with migraine.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of People With "Severe" Scores on the Migraine Disability Assessment
primary_outcome.description: The MIDAS is a 5-item, self-report instrument that assesses the number of days in the past three months participants experienced partially or fully reduced functioning in a variety of contexts (work, school, social). MIDAS scores are totaled and interpreted in the following grades: 0-5 = Grade I (Little or no disability); 6-10 = Grade II (Mild disability); 11-20 = Grade III (Moderate disability); 21+ = Grade IV (Severe disability). Scores were dichotomized at "Not Severe" (Grades I, II, and III) and "Severe "(Grade IV). The outcome was the proportion of participants who reported "Severe Disability."
25-item, self-report questionnaire of the emotional and functional impact of headache on daily activities. Total scores range from 0-100, with higher scores indicating higher levels of disability.

secondary_outcome.description: Number of headache days/month for the month prior to treatment, and the month after treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Average Headache Severity for Headache Days Recorded Over 30 Days
secondary_outcome.description: Headache Severity was recorded for every headache day on a scale of 0 = None, 1 = Mild, 2 = Moderate, 3 = Severe. Average headache severity was averaged across all headache days for each month.

13-item self-report measure that conveys a participant's level of pain-related, catastrophic thinking during painful experiences. Total scores range from 0-52, with higher scores indicating higher levels of catastrophizing.
20-item, self-report measure of pain-related acceptance. Total scores range from 0-156 with higher scores indicating higher pain acceptance.
39-item self-report instrument assessing mindfulness. Total scores range from 39-195, with higher scores indicating higher levels of mindfulness.

33-item measure designed to assess the extent to which individuals with recurrent headaches expect that the occurrence, worsening, and improvement of their headaches are influenced primarily by their own behavior, by chance or fate, or by the actions of medical professionals. Total scores range from 33-165, with higher scores indicating more external (vs. internal) locus of control.

25-item self-report scale designed to capture the confidence a patient believes they have in their own abilities to prevent headache episodes and manage their pain. Total scores range from 25-175, with higher scores indicating higher levels of self-efficacy

8-item self-report measure that assesses emotional distress in the past week focusing on negative mood and negative self-views. Scores are normed using T-scores (M = 50, SD = 10) with higher scores indicating higher levels of depressive symptoms.

8-item self-report measure that assesses emotional distress in the past week focusing on fear, worry and hyper-arousal. Scores were normed using T-scores (M = 50, SD = 10) with higher scores indicating higher levels of anxious symptoms.

A daily 4-item measure of migraine related disability. Scores range from 0-10, with higher scores indicating higher levels of disability. Scores are averaged across all headache days recorded each month.

arm_group.description: In this arm, participants will receive 8 weeks of the manualized treatment Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT; Day & Thorn). Participants will attend weekly 75-90 minute individual sessions for eight weeks. At each weekly session one of eight broad topics are addressed and discussed (Automatic-Pilot, Dealing with Barriers, Mindfulness of Breath, Staying Present, Allowing/Letting Be, Cognitive Restructuring, Self Care, Application to Headache Pain). Homework is assigned each week, and participants are expected to develop a daily formal mindfulness practice (body scan meditation, seated meditation, breathing meditation, etc). Participants are provided with a course manual, reading materials, and audio recordings to facilitate meditation practice.
Patients will continue with standard care. Patients will be offered MBCT after the primary endpoint.

intervention.description: 8 75-90 minute individual sessions of the manualized Mindfulness-based Cognitive Therapy plus a manual and homework

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ICHD-3 beta headache diagnosis of migraine,
- self-reported and diary-confirmed 4-20 headache days per month
- aged 18-65
- ability to read English
- capacity to consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- no ICHD-3 beta headache diagnosis of migraine
- fewer than 4 or greater than 20 headache days per month
- under 18 or over 65
- inability to read English
- lacking the capacity to consent
- utilization of new preventative pain treatments within four weeks of the baseline assessment, or a plan to utilize new preventive pain medications during the duration of the study
- severe psychiatric illness that would interfere with participation in the treatment

overall_official.affiliation: Yeshiva University/Albert Einstein College of Medicine

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: MBCT for Migraine
group.description: In this arm, participants will receive 8 weeks of the manualized treatment Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT; Day & Thorn). Participants will attend weekly 75-90 minute individual sessions for eight weeks. At each weekly session one of eight broad topics are addressed and discussed (Automatic-Pilot, Dealing with Barriers, Mindfulness of Breath, Staying Present, Allowing/Letting Be, Cognitive Restructuring, Self Care, Application to Headache Pain). Homework is assigned each week, and participants are expected to develop a daily formal mindfulness practice (body scan meditation, seated meditation, breathing meditation, etc). Participants are provided with a course manual, reading materials, and audio recordings to facilitate meditation practice. category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Headache Disability Inventory (HDI)
measure.description: The HDI is a scale that ranges from 0-100, with higher scores indicating higher levels of headache disability.

measure.title: Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) Score >=21
measure.description: The MIDAS is a scale that assesses the number of days in the past three months participants experienced partially or fully reduced functioning in a variety of contexts (work, school, social). MIDAS scores are totaled and interpreted in the following grades: 0-5 = Grade I (Little or no disability); 6-10 = Grade II (Mild disability); 11-20 = Grade III (Moderate disability); 21+ = Grade IV (Severe disability). Scores were dichotomized at "Not Severe" (Grades I, II, and III) and "Severe "(Grade IV).

outcome.title: Proportion of People With "Severe" Scores on the Migraine Disability Assessment
outcome.description: The MIDAS is a 5-item, self-report instrument that assesses the number of days in the past three months participants experienced partially or fully reduced functioning in a variety of contexts (work, school, social). MIDAS scores are totaled and interpreted in the following grades: 0-5 = Grade I (Little or no disability); 6-10 = Grade II (Mild disability); 11-20 = Grade III (Moderate disability); 21+ = Grade IV (Severe disability). Scores were dichotomized at "Not Severe" (Grades I, II, and III) and "Severe "(Grade IV). The outcome was the proportion of participants who reported "Severe Disability."

measure.title: Proportion of People With "Severe" Scores on the Migraine Disability Assessment
measure.description: The MIDAS is a 5-item, self-report instrument that assesses the number of days in the past three months participants experienced partially or fully reduced functioning in a variety of contexts (work, school, social). MIDAS scores are totaled and interpreted in the following grades: 0-5 = Grade I (Little or no disability); 6-10 = Grade II (Mild disability); 11-20 = Grade III (Moderate disability); 21+ = Grade IV (Severe disability). Scores were dichotomized at "Not Severe" (Grades I, II, and III) and "Severe "(Grade IV). The outcome was the proportion of participants who reported "Severe Disability."

analysis.p_value_desc: Significance threshold set a priori at .025 to adjust for two co-primary outcomes.
analysis.method_desc: The key test was the Treatment (MBCT-M vs. WL.TAU) X Time (Month 1 vs 4) interaction with both Treatment and Time in the model.
analysis.estimate_desc: A positive slope indicates greater reduction in the proportino of people with Severe MIDAS scores (Score >=21) in the MBCT-M group vs. the WL/TAU group.

outcome.title: Headache-Related Disability Index
outcome.description: 25-item, self-report questionnaire of the emotional and functional impact of headache on daily activities. Total scores range from 0-100, with higher scores indicating higher levels of disability.

outcome.description: 33-item measure designed to assess the extent to which individuals with recurrent headaches expect that the occurrence, worsening, and improvement of their headaches are influenced primarily by their own behavior, by chance or fate, or by the actions of medical professionals. Total scores range from 33-165, with higher scores indicating more external (vs. internal) locus of control.

reported_events.desc: Adverse events were tracked on a monthly basis by research staff in both groups. Participants in the MBCT-M group were also tracked weekly by the study therapist during the two-month treatment period (Month 2 and Month 3).

event.sub_title: Increase in headache frequency and intensity
event.description: Sudden and severe increase in headache frequency and intensity
A vivid recollection of a traumatic event

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.organization: Yeshiva University & Albert Einstein College of Medicine
